edge: Christopher Nolan wrote and directed the science fiction action film Inception in 2010.
In the film Inception, Leonardo DiCaprio plays a professional thief who steals information by infiltrating the subconscious of his targets.
Christopher Nolan produced Inception with his wife Emma Thomas in 2010.
Warner Bros. Produced and distributed the film Inception in 2010.
In 2002, Christopher Nolan presented a written 80-page treatment for a horror film to Warner Bros. About 'dream stealers', based on lucid dreaming.

node_2: more experience before tackling a production of this magnitude and complexity
edge: After completing Insomnia in 2002, Christopher Nolan decided to shelve his 'dream stealers' project as he needed more experience before tackling a production of this magnitude and complexity.
Christopher Nolan's reputation and success with The Dark Knight helped secure the film's US$100 million in advertising expenditure for Inception.
Inception was filmed in six countries, beginning in Tokyo on June 19 and ending in Canada on November 22.
The official budget for Inception was $160 million, split between Warner Bros. And Legendary.

node_2: leonardo dicaprio, joseph gordon-levitt, marion cotillard, elliot page, tom hardy, cillian murphy, tom berenger, dileep rao, and michael caine.
edge: The ensemble cast of Inception includes Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Marion Cotillard, Elliot Page, Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, Tom Berenger, Dileep Rao, and Michael Caine.
Inception, an acclaimed film directed by Christopher Nolan, premiered in London on July 8, 2010, and was released worldwide in both conventional and IMAX theaters beginning on July 16, 2010.
Inception is a film directed by Christopher Nolan, known for his successful works in the genre of science fiction and thriller movies.
Dom Cobb and Arthur are 'extractors' who perform corporate espionage using experimental dream-sharing technology to infiltrate their targets' subconscious and extract information.
The latest target of Cobb and Arthur is Saito, who is impressed with Cobb's ability to layer multiple dreams within each other. The son of Saito's competitor, Maurice Fischer, is also mentioned.
Saito offers to hire Cobb for the job of implanting an idea into a person's subconscious; performing 'inception' on Robert Fischer, the son of Saito's competitor Maurice Fischer.
In return for completing this task for Saito, Cobb will be granted clearance to return home to his children.
The ultimate goal of the operation is to implant an idea into Robert Fischer's subconscious, which will cause his father's company to dissolve.
Robert Fischer and his father Maurice are both associated with 'subconscious,' as Cobb and Arthur plan to infiltrate their subconsciouses during the operation.
Cobb accepts the offer and assembles his team, which includes Eames.
They are both members of Cobb's dream extraction team.
Ariadne is tasked with designing the dream's architecture, something Cobb himself cannot do for fear of being sabotaged by his mind's projection of his late wife, Mal.
After waking up, Mal still believed she was dreaming. Attempting to 'wake up,' she committed suicide and framed Cobb for her murder to force him to do the same.
The team sedates Robert Fischer into a three-layer shared dream on an airplane to America bought by Saito.
Eames impersonates Robert's godfather, Peter Browning, to introduce the idea of an alternate will to dissolve the company.
While dying in the dream would usually awaken dreamers, Yusuf's sedatives will instead send them into 'Limbo': a world of infinite subconscious.
After being wounded, Saito reveals that while dying in the dream would usually awaken dreamers, Yusuf's sedatives will instead send them into 'Limbo': a world of infinite subconscious.

When Nolan first started thinking about making the film, he was influenced by 'that era of movies where you had The Matrix...', implying a similarity between the themes and style of Inception and The Matrix.
Nolan was influenced by 'that era of movies where you had The Matrix (1999), you had Dark City...', suggesting a correlation between the genres and visuals of Inception and Dark City.
Nolan's initial inspiration for Inception came from 'that era of movies where you had The Matrix (1999), you had Dark City...', which also included The Thirteenth Floor.
Nolan's reference to 'that era of movies where you had The Matrix (1999), you had Dark City...', which also encompassed Memento.
Nolan realized that a movie like Inception required a vast budget as 'as soon as you're talking about dreams, the potential of the human mind is infinite.'
After pitching Inception to Warner Bros. In 2001, Nolan felt that he needed more experience making large-scale movies and began working on Batman Begins.
Nolan worked on Batman Begins before embarking on The Dark Knight, which he completed after making The Dark Knight and spent six months completing the script.
Nolan had been trying to work with Leonardo DiCaprio for years and met him several times, but was unable to recruit him for any of his films until Inception.
DiCaprio finally agreed because he was 'intrigued by this concept—this dream-heist notion and how this character's going to unlock his dreamworld and ultimately affect his real life.'
Nolan took a long time re-writing the script in order 'to make sure that the emotional journey of his [DiCaprio's] character was the driving force of the movie.'
Warner Bros. Purchased Inception, a spec script written by Nolan.
Principal photography began in Tokyo on June 19, 2009,

node_2: corridor that spun like 'a giant hamster wheel'
edge: Joseph Gordon-Levitt spent several weeks learning to fight in the corridor that spun like 'a giant hamster wheel'. Nolan described the device as 'like some incredible torture device' and admitted that they 'thrashed Joseph for weeks', but the unique rhythm of the footage made it look unlike anything any of them had seen before. Gordon-Levitt remembered that filming in the corridor was a six-day week affair, during which time he came home battered every night. The light fixtures on the ceiling came around on the floor and choosing the right time to cross through them was crucial because falling would have happened otherwise.
Filming for the sequences occurring inside a Paris college of architecture in the story took place at University College London, specifically at the library, Flaxman Gallery and Gustav Tuck Theatre.

node_2: cobb entering the college of architecture
edge: Filming moved to France and the place used for the entrance was the Musée Galliera.

edge: Filming moved to France and the bistro scene was shot at the corner of Rue César Franck and Rue Bouchut.

edge: Filming moved to France, where they shot the pivotal scenes between Ariadne and Cobb, on the Bir-Hakeim bridge.

Cobb hired Eames and Yusuf in Tangier,

node_2: important riot scene during the initial foray into saito's mind
edge: Tangier was also used as the setting for filming an important riot scene during the initial forray into Saito's mind.
The production staged a multi-vehicle car chase on the streets of downtown Los Angeles.
The L.A. weather stayed typically sunny during the car chase, but the filmmakers set up elaborate effects to give the audience the impression that the weather was overcast and soggy.

This sequence was filmed on and off for months, with the van being shot out of a cannon, according to actor Dileep Rao. The scene where a Ford Econoline van runs off the Schuyler Heim Bridge in slow motion is climactic.
Filming moved to the Los Angeles area, where some sets were built on a Warner Bros. sound stage, including the interior rooms of Saito's Japanese castle.
The exterior of Saito's Japanese castle was done on a small set built in Malibu Beach.
The dining room was inspired by the historic Nijō Castle, built around 1603.
The film was shot primarily in the anamorphic format on 35 mm film.
Key sequences were filmed on 65 mm, and aerial sequences in VistaVision.

Nolan did not shoot any footage with IMAX cameras as he had with The Dark Knight because given that it deals with a potentially surreal area, the nature of dreams and so forth, I wanted it to be as realistic as possible. Not be bound by the scale of those IMAX cameras, even though I love the format dearly
Nolan and Pfister tested using Showscan and Super Dimension 70 as potential large-format, high-frame-rate camera systems to use for the film, but ultimately decided against either format.
Sequences in slow motion were filmed on a Photo-Sonics 35 mm camera at speeds of up to 1,000 frames per second.

node_2: photo-sonics camera and 35 mm running through it
edge: Out of six times that we shot on the digital format, we only had one usable piece and it didn't end up in the film. Out of the six times we shot with the Photo-Sonics camera and 35 mm running through it, every single shot was in the movie.
Nolan has also criticized the dim image that 3D projection causes

Nolan's preference for shooting on film and using prime lenses in his movies, as it allows for a shallower depth of field and greater control over the focus and perspective compared to digital cameras with zoom lenses or 3D cameras.
Nolan's argument that shooting on film allows for realistic depth perception in traditional films, as opposed to the dim image produced by 3D projection.
Nolan's distinction between traditional films and 3D movies, and his belief that the latter's title is misleading because both are three-dimensional.
Nolan's decision to test converting Inception into 3D in post-production, but ultimately deciding against it due to a lack of time to complete the conversion to his satisfaction.
Liebesman's suggestion that Warner Bros. Were attempting a 3D conversion for Blu-ray release of Nolan's movie.

Franklin had artists build concepts while Nolan expressed his ideal vision of 'Something glacial, with clear modernist architecture, but with chunks of it breaking off into the sea like icebergs'. The result was a cityscape that looked like an iceberg version of Gotham City with water running through it.
The continually developing 'Limbo' city level during production resulted in a complex, yet organic-looking, cityscape created by Franklin and his team.
Franklin had artists producing concept sketches for the Paris-folding sequence.
Later during principal photography, Nolan was able to direct DiCaprio and Page based on the rough computer animation that Franklin had created.
Inception had nearly 500 visual effects shots, which is relatively few in comparison to contemporary effects-heavy films, which can have as many as 2,000 visual effects shots.
Hans Zimmer wrote the score for Inception, which he described as 'a very electronic, dense score' filled with 'nostalgia and sadness' to match Cobb's feelings throughout the film.

The music for Inception features a guitar sound reminiscent of Ennio Morricone, played by Johnny Marr.
A soundtrack album was released on July 11, 2010, for Inception by Reprise Records.
The majority of the score was also included in high resolution 5.1 surround sound on the second disc of the two-disc Blu-ray release.

Nolan wanted to explore 'the idea of people sharing a dream space... That gives you the ability to access somebody’s unconscious mind. What would that be used and abused for?' The majority of the film's plot takes place in these interconnected dream worlds.

node_2: actions in real or dream worlds ripple across others
edge: This structure creates a framework where actions in the real or dream worlds ripple across others.
Alluding to theories of social control developed by thinkers Michel Foucault and Jean Baudrillard.
According to one interpretation Nolan's world has more in common with the works of Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari.

node_2: belle de jour and the discreet charm of the bourgeoisie
edge: David Denby in The New Yorker compared Nolan's cinematic treatment of dreams to Luis Buñuel's in Belle de Jour (1967) and The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie (1972).

node_2: literal-minded action level sequencing compared to buñuel
edge: Denby criticized Nolan's 'literal-minded' action level sequencing compared to Buñuel, who 'silently pushed us into reveries and left us alone to enjoy our wonderment, but Nolan is working on so many levels of representation at once that he has to lay in pages of dialogue just to explain what’s going on.'

node_2: captures 'the peculiar malign intensity of actual dreams'
edge: Denby: 'The latter captures “the peculiar malign intensity of actual dreams.”'
Nolan combined elements from several different film genres into the film, notably science fiction, heist film, and film noir.

Marion Cotillard plays 'Mal' Cobb, Dom Cobb's projection of his guilt over his deceased wife’s suicide. As the film's main antagonist, she is a frequent, malevolent presence in his dreams. Dom is unable to control these projections of her, challenging his abilities as an extractor.
Nolan described Mal as 'the essence of the femme fatale', the key noir reference in the film.

node_2: cobb's own neurosis and fear of how little he knows about the woman he loves.
edge: DiCaprio praised Cotillard’s performance saying that 'she can be strong and vulnerable and hopeful and heartbreaking all in the same moment, which was perfect for all the contradictions of her character'.

node_2: greater emotional narrative suited to the world of dreams and subconscious
edge: Nolan began with the structure of a heist movie, since exposition is an essential element of that genre, though adapted it to have a greater emotional narrative suited to the world of dreams and subconscious.
In a traditional heist movie, there is a heavy dose of exposition at the beginning as the team assembles and the leader explains the plan.
Exposition becomes nearly continuous as the group progresses through the various levels of dreaming in Inception
The outer shell of the story is an elaborate caper
Until the van begins to fall from the bridge, three quarters of the film are devoted to explaining its plot.
Exposition takes precedence over characterization in Inception
Ariadne, like her ancient namesake, creates the maze and guides the others through it,
And as the sole student of dream sharing, helps the audience understand the concept of the plot.

The official trailer for Inception, released on May 10, 2010, was extremely well received and featured an original piece of music called 'Mind Heist' by recording artist Zack Hemsey. Mind Game also released a trailer around the same time, which is where the term originated from.
The trend of 'braam' sounds in blockbuster movie trailers can be traced back to Inception, as its trailers were widely credited for launching this trend throughout the 2010s.
Blockbuster movie trailers repeatedly hit audiences with so-called 'braam' sounds: bassy, brassy, thunderous notes meant to impart a sense of apocalyptic momentousness.

node_2: teaser trailer, first trailer, second trailer, and film score
edge: Different composers worked on the teaser trailer, first trailer, second trailer, and film score of Inception, making it a complicated task to identify the composer(s) responsible for launching the trend of 'braam' sounds in blockbuster movie trailers.

The film's self-referential and tongue-in-cheek elements suggest that it is a film about film-making. Critics like Devin Faraci make this argument by analyzing the ambiguity of the ending and its connection to the theme of dreams within dreams.

The film explores the concept of dreams through its unique storytelling structure, which involves entering into a person's dream and then another dream within that dream. This theme is further explored in the ambiguity of the ending, where it is unclear whether the characters have awoken from their dreams or are still inside them.
The film also employs religious and water symbolism to explore the idea of dreams, including references to baptism and the notion that the mind is a vast ocean waiting to be explored.
Some critics have interpreted Inception as a Christian allegory, drawing parallels between the film's themes of salvation, redemption, and forgiveness to biblical stories.

The film's structure is also noteworthy, with its use of continuous exposition resulting in a unique narrative that reveals information as it becomes necessary. This approach to storytelling has been praised by critics like Kristin Thompson.

Several critics and scholars have noted the similarities between Inception and the anime film Paprika, both in terms of plot and characters. These comparisons suggest that Inception may have been influenced by Paprika.
The Dream of a Lifetime, a comic by Don Rosa, has also been cited as a potential influence on Inception due to its similar plot elements.
The influence of Tarkovsky's Solaris on Inception has also been noted by some critics and scholars.

node_2: most-mentioned films in top ten lists (2010)
edge: Inception appeared on over 273 critics' lists of the top ten films of 2010, making it one of the most critically acclaimed films of that year.
At least 55 critics ranked Inception as number-one on their top ten lists of the best films of 2010.
While Inception was one of the most critically acclaimed films of 2010, some critics ranked other movies, such as The Social Network and Toy Story 3, above it.
Author Stephen King placed Inception at No. 3 in his list of top 10 best films of the year.

node_2: bbc radio 1 and bbc radio 1xtra listeners' favorite film of all time
edge: The film was voted by BBC Radio 1 and BBC Radio 1Xtra listeners as their ninth-favorite film of all time in March 2011.
Producer Roger Corman cited Inception as an example of 'great imagination and originality'.
Total Film named it the most-rewatchable movie of all time in 2012.
Empire ranked Inception the tenth-greatest film ever made on their list of 'The 301 Greatest Movies Of All Time' as voted by the magazine's readers in 2014.

node_2: second-best science fiction film since the turn of the century
edge: Rolling Stone magazine named it the second-best science fiction film since the turn of the century in 2014.
The film was ranked 84th on Hollywood's 100 Favorite Films, a list compiled by The Hollywood Reporter in 2014, surveying 'Studio chiefs, Oscar winners and TV royalty'.

node_2: the most influential visual effects films of all time'
edge: The film was included in the Visual Effects Society's list of 'The Most Influential Visual Effects Films of All Time'.
Total Film named Inception the best film of the 2010s in 2019.

In April 2014, The Daily Telegraph placed the title 'most overrated films' on its top ten list. This indicates that while 'The Inception' may be considered highly acclaimed by some, The Daily Telegraph disagrees and considers it overrated.

'The Inception' purports to be about people's dreams being invaded, but demonstrates no instinct at all for what a dream has ever felt like, and no flair for making us feel like we're in one, at any point.' This statement made by Tim Robey suggests that while 'The Inception' explores the concept of people's dreams being invaded, it fails to accurately portray the feeling or experience of a dream.

'It's a criminal failing of the movie that it purports to be about people's dreams being invaded, but demonstrates no instinct at all for what a dream has ever felt like, and no flair for making us feel like we're in one, at any point.' This quote by Tim Robey implies that while 'The Inception' is primarily about the concept of people's dreams being invaded, its portrayal of this concept is severely flawed or lacking.
According to an informal poll by the Los Angeles Times, 'The Inception' was deemed as the most overrated movie of 2010.

node_2: academy awards for best cinematography, best sound editing, best sound mixing, and best visual effects
edge: The Inception won several awards in technical categories at the Academy Awards, including Best Cinematography, Best Sound Editing, Best Sound Mixing, and Best Visual Effects.

node_2: british academy film awards for best production design, best special visual effects and best sound
edge: 'The Inception' won the British Academy Film Awards for Best Production Design, Best Special Visual Effects, and Best Sound.

node_2: two highest honors for a science fiction or fantasy film: the 2011 bradbury award and the 2011 hugo award
edge: 'The Inception' won two prestigious awards, including the 2011 Bradbury Award for best dramatic production and the 2011 Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation (Long Form), which are considered as the highest honors for a science fiction or fantasy film.

node_2: the social network and the king's speech
edge: 'The Inception' was defeated by 'The Social Network' or 'The King's Speech' in most of its artistic nominations at various award shows, including the Oscars, BAFTAs, and Golden Globes.

Numerous pop and hip hop songs reference the film, including Common's 'Blue Sky', N.E.R.D.'s 'Hypnotize U', XV's 'The Kick', Black Eyed Peas' 'Just Can't Get Enough', Lil Wayne's '6 Foot 7 Foot', Jennifer Lopez's 'On the Floor', and B.o.B's 'Strange Clouds'

The second episode of the animated comedy show Rick and Morty parodied the film.
In an episode of The Simpsons, named 'How I Wet Your Mother', the plot spoofs Inception with various scenes parodying moments from the film.
The showrunners of the television series The Flash said its season 4 finale was inspired by Inception.
American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift released a lyric video for her single 'The Man', which featured visuals bearing resemblance to the film.
The film's title has been colloquialized as the suffix -ception, which can be jokingly appended to a noun to indicate a layering, nesting, or recursion of the thing in question.
